nodes.text: When the government can use commodity and income taxes but not lump-sum taxes, choosing taxes and public production jointly can maximize social welfare and may make aggregate production efficiency desirable

In a one-consumer economy with government-controlled production and commodity taxation, the welfare maximization problem can be expressed as choosing consumer prices q to maximize an indirect welfare function V(q) subject to the production feasibility constraint G(x(q))<=0

Under assumptions of constant returns to scale in private sector, competitive private production (zero profits), differentiable production functions, and commodity taxes only, the planner's Lagrangian yields first-order conditions that determine optimal relationships between producer prices p and consumer prices q (hence taxes t)

Many-consumer economies can be analyzed using the same indirect-welfare-as-a-function-of-prices approach V(q)=U(x1(q),...,xH(q)) and similar conclusions about production efficiency and optimal taxes prevail under mild additional assumptions

The paper uses a sequence of analyses: geometric depiction (two-commodity, one consumer), algebraic calculus derivation, extension to many consumers, and rigorous theorems establishing existence and efficiency conditions

Geometric analysis (offer curve and production frontier) implies that, for one consumer, any interior production plan is dominated by some point on the production frontier so the optimum lies on the frontier when decentralization is constrained to price-based trades

From the Lagrangian first-order conditions: (i) equality of marginal rates of transformation between public and private production (aggregate production efficiency) holds when the welfare multiplier X is nonzero; (ii) consumer and producer prices relate so that marginal welfare gains from price changes equal X times the marginal cost impact, which gives optimal tax structure conditions
Conclusion: Aggregate production efficiency is desirable in a wide variety of circumstances even when lump-sum taxes are unavailable and a full Pareto optimum is not achievable

In many-consumer economies, if aggregate demand X(q) is continuous and social welfare respects individual preferences, then raising some consumers' utilities without lowering others can be achieved by price tweaks, supporting the desirability of production efficiency; a mild condition (existence of some good with unilateral supply or demand) ensures weak efficiency

Rigorous theorems: under assumptions on consumption sets, preferences continuity/convexity, and closedness/convexity and boundedness conditions on the production set, an optimum exists and the attainable set is nonempty and bounded (Theorems 1-3)

Interpretation of tax first-order conditions: when welfare is individualistic, the marginal utility of a price change equals a constant times marginal tax revenue change at constant producer prices, yielding testable proportionality conditions for optimal taxes (Ramsey-style result)

Limitations and counterexamples: there exist cases where an interior (inefficient) production plan is optimal (constructed examples) or where constraints on tax instruments, presence of pure profits, fixed prices, externalities, or migration can alter continuity and so invalidate the efficiency conclusion

Extensions: adding intermediate goods, untaxable sectors, international trade, migration, consumption externalities, and capital market imperfections generally preserves the schematic result that sectors without consumers should be organized to achieve aggregate production efficiency, though optimal taxes change to reflect the specific constraints

Final conclusion: With sufficiently flexible commodity taxation and under standard regularity assumptions, optimal commodity taxes can be set so that aggregate production is efficient; the optimal tax structure is characterized by first-order conditions balancing marginal welfare gains and marginal revenue costs, and exceptions occur only when instruments or assumptions are restricted
